data.title: webview search results highlights too bright
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.15 Insiders
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1.Bring up release notes (Help > Release Notes)
2.Ctrl+F to open the new search and type "bugs"

The first selection is bright orange and the second is yellow. They look very bright on Dark+ theme.

We should use the same search selection colors as the editor and be theme aware.

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Consider renaming the "window" classification of settings to "workbench"
data.body:
The 1.15 release notes mention the new classification of settings into "window" specific and "resource" specific. "Window" is a much used term in VS Code docs and usually applies to a specific VS Code instance (New Window, Switch Window, Reload Window). I think a better term for these types of settings would be "workbench" specific and we use the "workbench." scope on many settings that apply to the overall VS Code UI.

I'm not sure if the "window" setting classification is surfaced in the UI or if the distinction is just for documentation descriptions and perhaps the internal implementation.

data.title: don't apply indentation rule while inside raw strings
data.body:
allow code like this
```ts
const myString = `some
long
 indented
  string`;
```

data.title: Hover doesn't disappear when select the word which has hover message
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.15 Insider
- OS Version: macOS

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Hover on a word which has good intellisense, wait for the hover to show up
2. Mouse down on the word
3. Move the cursor to select characters, you can scroll the page to select content in multiple pages
4. You can see the hover doesn't disappear

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/876920/28735392-cdb57214-7399-11e7-8796-1ad8e56c286d.png)

From above image, you can see the last three lines has a hover overlay above it.


<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No

data.title: Scope toggleFind* keyboard shortcuts to a new context
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.15.0-insider (0e7546c978fa1b62dbf36f07a77d1b9a4241d6f7, 2017-07-28T11:23:06.089Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.16251
---

Originally reported here https://github.com/eamodio/vscode-gitlens/issues/113

Could `ctrl+d` (select next occurrence) start a context/scope so that the keyboard shortcuts below could be registered in vscode with a `when` on that new context?

For example:
```json
{ "key": "alt+c",                 "command": "toggleFindCaseSensitive",
                                     "when": "editorFocus && inFindNext" },
{ "key": "alt+l",                 "command": "toggleFindInSelection",
                                     "when": "editorFocus && inFindNext" },
{ "key": "alt+r",                 "command": "toggleFindRegex",
                                     "when": "editorFocus && inFindNext" },
{ "key": "alt+w",                 "command": "toggleFindWholeWord",
                                     "when": "editorFocus && inFindNext" },
```

Is that reasonable and feasible?

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: No

data.title: Copy one file from a VS Code window(project) to another one
data.body:
Right now in left side explorer if you right click on a file and copy it, you can easily paste it in that explorer in another place, which is a very good thing.
but you cannot copy and paste it to explorer which is opened for another project in another VS Code window.

<!DOCTYPE html>

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->

This is something I like to use when I'm supposed to darkenize colors.

data.title: Search exclude settings are not properly resolved when doing a search with `./`
data.body: Search exclude settings are resolved against the searchPath, not the workspace that they are associated with.

data.title: Update dotnet build task
data.body: By updating the task configuration to 2.0.0 the task name doesn't get automatically appended to the command. The correct build command for dotnet should therefore be 'dotnet build'.

data.title: Support variables in terminal.integrated.cwd

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
The exact format of variables would rely on some investigation into the other settings. We use a common syntax like `${env.HOME}`, `${workspaceRoot}`, etc. (as `$HOME`/`%HOME%` is not cross-platform).

/cc @millergarym

data.title: Holding down a key in the terminal only sends a single key on Mac

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Upstream issue: https://github.com/sourcelair/xterm.js/issues/265
Related: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/10398

Repro steps:

1. Focus terminal and hold the <kbd>a</kbd> key, only a single character is added to the prompt

data.title: Drop support for variable substition for program and runtime in package.json
data.body:
Stop supporting variable substitution (e.g. `${workspaceRoot}`) inside the `package.json` `runtime` and `program` fields.

Affected are exactly these two attributes in the `debuggers` contribution:
![2017-08-07_20-25-31](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1898161/29040306-ca6587b2-7bae-11e7-8510-e6d5ef00c695.png)

We have never marketed this feature and now it is providing some debt when introducing multi root workspaces (as the package.json can not specify against which root to resolve the variables against)

data.title: Emmet conflicts with Intellisense while editing HTML
data.body:
I'm new to VS Code and as a Emmet user I'm finding problems using it with this editor. The most annoying part for me is that seems to be a conflict between Emmet and Intellisense. I'm giving an example bellow.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create an html file.
2. Write `!` and press tab to generate an html skeleton.
3. On the body section, type `p` and press tab.

The expected behavior would be to generate a `p` element. Instead, the editor (intellisense) show `DOCTYPE` as an autocomplete option and when I press tab, `DOCTYPE` is written in the file.

The same problem occurs if disabling extensions, and for other html files, other options are suggested. In a bigger html file inside a subdirectory, options like `pack` are shown.

data.title: Go to implementation should support loading indicators
data.body:
I suggest that `ImplementationProvider` should support asynchronous loading indication in the same way as `ReferenceProvider`.

My understanding based on [other conversation](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-go/pull/1100#issuecomment-318285633) is that the current assumption with `ImplementationProviders` is that they will return almost immediately.

In popular languages which actually enable the static analysis to drive implementation finding (e.g. Java, Go), I think it's reasonable to expect the analysis to take more than a few seconds (see https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-go/pull/1100), and the current API behavior means users are in the dark about what's happening while the analysis is processing.

data.title: Add more progress UI locations, e.g editor and sidebar
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.15.0-insider (0e7546c978fa1b62dbf36f07a77d1b9a4241d6f7, 2017-07-28T11:23:06.089Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.16251

Currently `withProgress` supports 2 locations: `SourceControl` which shows a nice "progress bar" on the source control activity, and `Window` which shows a spinner and message in the statusbar (imo this should be called `StatusBar`). I would love to have 1 or 2 additional locations -- something like `SideBar` where it would show the "progress bar" on any activity currently active in the the side bar, and/or `Editor` (would call it `Window` but that is used) where it would show the similar "progress bar" but instead of in the side bar, it would be on the active editor.

As an aside, I also found it confusing that when using `SourceControl` no progress message or anything needs to be set, but to use `Window` you must set at least 1 progress message otherwise no indicator shows.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No

data.title: Feature request: vscode extensions in json file
data.body:
# Feature request
## Feature
It would be nice to have a JSON file with all installed extensions and their versions, like package.json for node modules.

## Example
`extensions.json`
```json
 {
  "akamud.vscode-theme-onedark": "2.0.3",
  "ms-vscode.js-atom-grammar": "0.1.13",
  "...": "...",
}
```

## Use case
For those of us who switches often  between devices it would be easier to manage extensions.

testing #31457

As discussion over lunch, Suggesting to explore showing the color picker in a peek view as it allows for a more stable UI, which which unlock features like showing all colours of the document, host a pipette tool etc.
